title: Portland day trip: Wild and Scenic Sandy River beckons at Oxbow Regional Park (photos)
text:
The official Salmon Homecoming was held this past weekend at Oxbow Regional Park, but activities are always being offered by Metro at their regional parks and recreational areas .
Oxbow Regional Park offers a chance to commune with nature in an easy day trip from Portland. While on your way there for the spring wildflowers, summer camping or fall Chinook salmon spawning, stop in charming Troutdale or have a meal and brew at McMenamins Edgefield property.
Walk off that turkey dinner on November 22, 2015, during a Thanksgiving Walk from 10:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at Oxbow Regional Park, where 1,200 acres straddle the nationally designated Wild and Scenic Sandy River just outside of Troutdale. Naturalist Dan Daly and Deerdance School's Terry Kem lead the stroll along the river, followed by a campfire gathering to hear the "Thanksgiving Address" passed down by the Iroquois. Cost is $5 per vehicle or $7 per bus.
Picnic areas abound and can be rented by large groups, complete with shelters, tables, large barbecues and horseshoe pits.
Salmon spawning in Sandy River at Oxbow Regional Park Metro hosts Salmon Homecoming each year, inviting the community out to Oxbow Regional Park to take part in family-friendly activities with designated areas to watch the salmon spawning. By all accounts, this weekend's viewing was okay.
There are 57 drive-up campsites with picnic tables, fire pits and cooking grills. Free hot water showers are available.
During summer months there are campfire events each Friday and Saturday night that include live music, astronomy talks and puppet shows.
A boat ramp offers river access. The Sandy River Water Trail Paddle Guide is essential for anyone thinking of taking on any of the trail's 37 river miles that range in difficulty from class I to V.
Some things to keep in mind when visiting Oxbow Regional Park:
No dogs allowed , unless they are a service animal. There is a $5/vehicle or $7/bus fee. Annual parks passes are available , which includes access to Metro facilities with vehicle fees, including Blue Lake, Smith and Bybee Wetlands Natural Area and boat ramps . Construction on 20 new campsites is scheduled to start in spring 2016 and is estimated to last about two months. Here's a handy field guide to Oxbow Regional Park. Read more about Metro in a quarterly publication, Our Big Backyard , which contains feature stories, events and a photography contest. Learn more about the field trips and nature programs offered.
